item.title: Palabra del día en inglés: ‘convivial’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 60 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Japón se despide de los pandas chinos
item.description: En medio de las tensiones políticas entre Tokio y Pekín, los osos emblema de la diplomacia de China abandonan su cargo.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

media:content.media:description: Lei Lei, gemela de Xiao Xiao, disfrutando del bambú en el zoológico el domingo.

item.title: Cómo Irán reprimió un levantamiento ciudadano con fuerza letal
item.description: Las protestas estallaron en medio de un bloqueo de las comunicaciones. Pero a medida que surgen los videos y relatos de testigos, la brutalidad de la represión del régimen va quedando clara.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Sanjana Varghese, Malachy Browne and Parin Behrooz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:description: Videos and witness testimony reveal how Iran crushed a civilian uprising with lethal force.

item.title: En un país devastado por la guerra, los conciertos duran toda la noche
item.description: La vida en Birmania se trastornó hace cinco años, cuando los militares tomaron el poder. Ahora, la junta gobernante intenta proyectar una apariencia de legitimidad y normalidad.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Lauren DeCicca

media:content.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times

item.title: Word of the Day: convivial
item.description: This word has appeared in 60 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: ¿Puedo usar una sudadera en el trabajo?
item.description: Estas prendas, en versiones modernas y caras, están por todas partes, pero nuestra crítica ofrece algunas palabras de advertencia antes de que te pongas una para ir a la oficina.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: The Rise and Fall of South Korean First Lady Kim Keon Hee
item.description: Kim Keon Hee was unlike any presidential spouse South Korea had seen. Her downfall, on corruption charges, came after her husband declared martial law.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

media:content.media:description: Kim Keon Hee, South Korea’s former first lady, arrived for her first hearing on corruption charges at Seoul Central District Court in September.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 28, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 28, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Denmark’s Leader Questions How Long America Will Be Ally
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 28, 2025.

item.title: Corey Lewandowski, a Familiar Trumpworld Figure, Is at the Center of the ICE Uproar
item.description: Now a top aide to Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, Mr. Lewandowski has a long history of controversy in President Trump’s orbit, but he has always found a way back from exile.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:description: Corey Lewandowski and Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, met with President Trump on Monday for nearly two hours as the administration faced intense pressure to ease up federal immigration agents’ aggressive tactics in Minnesota.

item.title: Man Lunges at Ilhan Omar During Minneapolis Town Hall
item.description: During a town hall in Minneapolis, a man sitting directly in front of Representative Ilhan Omar rushed to the lectern and sprayed her with a pungent liquid. He was immediately tackled and removed from the room.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:description: A man rushed toward Representative Ilhan Omar, Democrat of Minnesota, and sprayed liquid on her on Tuesday night in Minneapolis.

item.title: Former Adams Aide Took Bribe of Diamond Earrings, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Prosecutors added new details to their case against Ingrid Lewis-Martin, who is accused of using her position in New York’s City Hall to help associates in exchange for bribes.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ingrid Lewis-Martin, who was chief adviser to New York City’s former mayor, Eric Adams, faces five corruption indictments.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 28, 2026
item.description: Kevin Curry’s crossword may end in a split decision.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Tails of the City: San Francisco’s Latest Animal Sensation Is a Mountain Lion
item.description: The 2-year-old male was safely captured after he got stuck between two apartment buildings.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight

item.title: Mountain Lion Spotted in San Francisco
item.description: Residents were shocked to see a young mountain lion roaming the streets of San Francisco this week. Local animal control agencies were able to capture and tranquilize it on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

item.title: The Most Important Foreign Policy Speech in Years
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s speech at Davos last week sent shock waves through the international community. The international-affairs scholar Henry Farrell explains why.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Dozens Arrested After Anti-ICE Protest at a Manhattan Hilton
item.description: The demonstration at the TriBeCa hotel followed a similar targeting of a Hilton property in Minneapolis on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan and Olivia Bensimon

media:content.media:description: Anti-ICE protesters and guests filled the lobby of a Hilton Garden Inn in Manhattan on Tuesday evening.

item.title: Democrats Restore Minnesota House to Even Split Amid Immigration Turmoil
item.description: In special elections on Tuesday, Democrats won two left-leaning districts, preventing Republicans from holding a majority in the State House of Representatives.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:credit: Liam James Doyle for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Minnesota House of Representatives at the Capitol in St. Paul.

item.title: U.S. Expects to Finish Review of Epstein Files Soon, Bondi Says
item.description: By law, the government was required to release its files on Jeffrey Epstein in December. Now the attorney general said they will be out “in the near term.”
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Attorney General Pam Bondi said in a filing that the Justice Department’s efforts to release the Epstein files involved hundreds of lawyers and other staff members.

item.title: 24 Tips for Better Health and Wellness
item.description: We asked doctors, therapists and other experts to sum up their best advice in a few memorable words.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Schupak

item.title: Noem’s Handling of Shooting Put Her in Trump’s Penalty Box, but Just Briefly
item.description: Kristi Noem’s aggressiveness has sometimes given President Trump heartburn. She got a rebuke after a second killing by federal immigration agents but soon seemed to be back in his good graces.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Hamed Aleaziz and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

media:content.media:description: The fatal shooting in Minnesota over the weekend was the latest episode in which high-profile efforts by Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, on behalf of President Trump’s policies have drawn intense criticism.

item.title: Man Rushes Ilhan Omar at Minneapolis Town Hall and Sprays Her
item.description: A man who had been sitting in the front row rushed at the Democratic representative and sprayed her with a strong-smelling liquid. He was removed by security and later booked into jail.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault, Lauren McCarthy and Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A man rushed toward Representative Ilhan Omar, Democrat of Minnesota, and sprayed liquid on her on Tuesday night in Minneapolis. Security officials tackled him.

item.title: Trump Demonizes ICE Detainees in Minnesota as ‘Vicious’ Criminals
item.description: Hours after saying that he might “de-escalate” an aggressive ICE crackdown in Minnesota, Trump portrayed those arrested by federal agents there as “hardened, vicious, horrible criminals.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Aishvarya Kavi

media:content.media:description: President Trump at the Horizon Events Center in Clive, Iowa, on Tuesday.

item.title: D.H.S. Review Does Not Say Pretti Brandished Gun, As Noem Claimed
item.description: An initial report from an internal agency watchdog says the Minneapolis man was shot by law enforcement after resisting arrest, but makes no mention of the allegations leveled by a Trump administration official.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo, Alexandra Berzon and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A makeshift memorial at the site where Alex Pretti was shot and killed by federal agents during an immigration enforcement operation.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Pull U.S. Help From Iraq if Former Leader Returns
item.description: Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a former prime minister, has been nominated to the post by the main Shiite Muslim bloc in the Iraqi Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

media:content.media:description: Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a former prime minister of Iraq, at a polling station in Baghdad in November.

item.title: Why Did the Trump Administration Silence Bovino on Social Media?
item.description: When the border chief got yanked from Minnesota, he lost access to his X account, too.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh

media:content.media:description: Gregory Bovino speaking in Minneapolis last week.

item.title: Who Decides When a Home Is Safe? A California Bill Says Science, Not Insurers.
item.description: Following a Times investigation, a state lawmaker is proposing the first health-based standards for assessing smoke contamination after wildfires.
item.dc:creator: Rukmini Callimachi and Blacki Migliozzi

media:content.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Days after the devastating Eaton fire last year, the Los Angeles community of Altadena was still smoldering.

item.title: Minnesota Leaders Meet With White House Border Czar
item.description: Gov. Tim Walz and the mayor of Minneapolis, Jacob Frey, met separately with the Trump aide Tom Homan on Tuesday. All three described the discussions as a productive starting point.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil, Ernesto Londoño and Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Trump Suggests He Will ‘De-Escalate’ in Minneapolis, Without Offering Details
item.description: President Trump continued to put the blame on Alex Pretti for legally carrying a weapon with a permit, saying, “You can’t walk in with guns.”
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi and David E. Sanger

media:content.media:description: President Trump speaking at the White House before leaving for Iowa on Tuesday.

item.title: Republicans Shift Tone After Killings, Criticizing Trump’s Immigration Push
item.description: With the president signaling a pivot in his crackdown, G.O.P. lawmakers have felt freer to express concern. But it’s not clear what they are willing to do about it.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse

media:content.media:description: Republicans in Congress have starkly shifted their tone on the Trump administration’s aggressive immigration crackdown, conceding that something must change.

item.title: Johnny Legend, a King of Trash Culture, Dies at 77
item.description: His forays into rockabilly music, wrestling and erotic films made him a cult hero in a career as confounding as that of his friend Andy Kaufman.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

media:content.media:description: Johnny Legend onstage in Atlanta in 2006. A self-described “rockabilly bastard,” among other things, he was known for his unhinged live performances.

item.title: City Prosecutors Join Forces to Bring Charges Against Federal Agents
item.description: Nine progressive prosecutors say they will work together to charge federal agents accused of wrongdoing, but they will face significant legal obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan

media:content.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman & Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times

item.title: Teenagers, After a Second Killing in Minneapolis, How Are You Feeling About Where America Is Now — and Where It Is Heading?
item.description: Federal agents fatally shot a second U.S. citizen on Saturday during protests of President Trump’s immigration crackdown, prompting many Americans to reflect on the state of the country. Teenagers, what do you think?
item.dc:creator: Natalie Proulx

media:content.media:description: A memorial for Alex Pretti at the spot where he was shot and killed by federal agents in Minneapolis.

item.title: Southwest Begins Assigned Seating, Scrapping a Signature Quirk
item.description: The airline said its new policy, rolled out on Tuesday, responded to passengers’ preferences, but some customers said the scramble was part of the charm.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

media:content.media:credit: Jacob Langston for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Southwest Airlines commemorated the end of its longstanding open-seating policy with a celebration on Tuesday morning at Orlando International Airport.

item.title: Virginia Judge Blocks Democrats’ Efforts to Redraw Congressional Maps
item.description: Democratic leaders vowed to appeal the lower court ruling, which found that the legislative process behind the redistricting push was improper.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson

media:content.media:description: The Virginia General Assembly convened earlier this month for a new session that included a vote on redistricting and an address by the state’s new Democratic governor, Abigail Spanberger, who greeted legislators, below, as she entered the chamber.

item.title: España abre una ruta de regularización migratoria, en contraste con el mundo
item.description: La medida, aprobada inesperadamente, llega en un momento en que otros países toman medidas enérgicas contra la inmigración.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista

media:content.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Un puesto de comida venezolana en Madrid a principios de enero. La medida aprobada el martes se aplicará a los migrantes indocumentados que ya viven en España, muchos de los cuales proceden de América Latina.

item.title: U.S. Population Growth Slows Sharply
item.description: Also, some good news for a Broadway musical. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Population growth in Florida slowed markedly last year, according to new census estimates.

item.title: Gladys West, Unsung Figure in Development of GPS, Dies at 95
item.description: As a Navy mathematician in the 1950s and beyond, she played an unheralded but foundational role in making possible the global satellite-based mapping system.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Democrats Push to Impeach DHS Secretary Kristi Noem After Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: Following the fatal shooting in Minneapolis, a drive to impeach the homeland security secretary has drawn dozens more Democratic supporters, including the party’s top three leaders.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: From left, Representatives Pete Aguilar, Democrat of California and the Democratic Caucus chair; Hakeem Jeffries, Democrat of New York and the minority leader; and Katherine Clark, Democrat of Massachusetts and the minority whip, at a news conference in Washington this month.

item.title: Trump Calls for ‘Honest’ Inquiry Into Alex Pretti Shooting
item.description: President Trump said that he will be “watching over” the investigation in the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti. He also said faulted Mr. Pretti for carrying a gun.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Fetherston and Cynthia Silva

media:content.media:description: President Trump talking to reporters near the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Judge Revives Wind Farm That Trump Halted Off Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: The project, known as Vineyard Wind, was already 95 percent complete when the Trump administration ordered construction to stop.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow

media:content.media:credit: Randi Baird for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Vineyard wind farm in the Atlantic Ocean off Martha’s Vineyard, Mass.

item.title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Deportation of 5-Year-Old Detained by ICE in Minnesota
item.description: An image of the boy, wearing a Spider-Man backpack as he was detained by federal agents, became a symbol of the immigration crackdown in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

media:content.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A protester holding an artwork of Liam Conejo Ramos in Portland, Maine, last week.

item.title: Immigration Enforcement Is Unavoidably Upsetting. But This Is Something Else.
item.description: Is this really the only way to enforce the law?
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

item.title: The Sauces and Seasonings Chefs Can’t Live Without
item.description: Expert-approved condiments and spices that will instantly upgrade your meals.
item.dc:creator: Martha Cheng

item.title: F.A.A. Ignored Safety Concerns Prior to Collision Over Potomac, N.T.S.B. Says
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board said that a “multitude of errors” led to the collision between a military helicopter and a commercial jet, killing 67 people last January.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jennifer Homendy, the National Transportation Safety Board chairwoman, speaking after the crash at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport last year. The board plans to publish a full report on the crash.

item.title: Peter H. Duesberg, 89, Renowned Biologist Turned H.I.V. Denialist, Dies
item.description: His pioneering work on the origins of cancer was later overshadowed by his contrarian views, notably his rejection of the established theory that H.I.V. causes AIDS.
item.dc:creator: Faye Flam

media:content.media:credit: Roger Ressmeyer/Corbis — VCG, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Peter H. Duesberg in 1985, holding a tray of petri dishes containing cultured cancer cells. In the late 1960s, he discovered the first known cancer-causing gene, or oncogene.

item.title: Should Iran’s Executioners Go Unpunished?
item.description: It’s left to the United States to impose meaningful consequences on the Iranian regime for one of the worst atrocities of this century.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: President Visits Iowa, Trying to Shift Focus to the Economy
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
